5.text:
One of the areas that a lot of new students
run into trouble with is referencing.

9.text:
I'm going to talk you through a commonly used
style known as Harvard referencing.

15.text:
When you're writing a piece of academic work,
you'll be researching and reading a lot of

19.text:
work done by others to help formulate your
ideas and arguments.

23.text:
You need to acknowledge where you found the
information; not only because it's fair to

27.text:
give credit to the person whose hard work
you're using, but also to avoid plagiarism.

34.text:
When using the Harvard referencing system,
there are two stages to highlighting other

37.text: people's work in your own, citing or referencing.

43.text:
Citing or citation is what you do in the text
of your essay, where you highlight words or

49.text:
ideas that you've incorporated from somebody
else's work.

55.text:
Referencing, is where you put all of the details
of the source of the information that you've

61.text:
used at the end of your work in a separate
section.

68.text:
The way that you use citation in your work,
depends on whether you're using a direct word

73.text:
for word quote from another piece of work
or if you're putting somebody else's ideas

81.text:
If you're copying a statement word for word,
you need to put quotation marks around it.

94.text:
If you're writing somebody else's ideas in
your own words, then you don't need to use

102.text:
For both direct quotes and putting somebody
else's work into your own words, you need

107.text:
to then indicate the source of the information,
in brackets, at the end.

119.text:
These details are there to lead the reader
to the full information at the back of the

131.text:
A citation only includes a maximum of three
pieces of information.

136.text:
If you're copying a direct quote, this will
be: the authors surname, the year the source

141.text: was published and the page number.

148.text:
If it's not a direct quote, you should include
the author and the year the source was published.

155.text:
The reference section of your work should
include all of the information about the source

161.text:
of the statement that you've used in your
essay.

166.text:
Each separate source of information should
always start with the same information as

170.text:
the citation in your essay, so the source
materials' details can easily be found.

183.text:
You should then organise each source alphabetically
by the author.

187.text:
If for any reason there is no author, you
should use the title of the source instead.

195.text:
Under the Harvard system, the order you present
the information for each of your sources has

199.text: to be done in a particular way.

202.text:
If you've got your information from a book,
then you need to write down the following:

208.text:
The author or editor, the year of publication
in round brackets, the title in italics; bold

223.text:
or underlined, the edition if it is not the
first edition, the place of publication and

232.text:
the publisher, the series and volume number
where relevant.

242.text:
If you used the information from an ebook
in your work, then you need to write down

246.text:
the following:
The author or editor, the

255.text:
year of publication in round brackets, the
title in italics; bold or underlined, name

266.text:
of the ebook collection in italics; bold or
underlined, the phrase "Online" in square

274.text:
brackets, the words "available at" followed
by the url of the ebook, the word "accessed"

284.text:
followed by the date you accessed the information
in brackets.

291.text:
If you used the information from a journal
in your work,

294.text:
The author, the 
year of publication in round brackets, the

309.text:
title of the article in single quotation marks,
the title of the journal in italics; bold

317.text:
or underlined and the volume, issue and page
numbers.

326.text:
If you used information from an online journal
in your work, then you need to write down

330.text:
the following:
The author, the year of publication in round

340.text:
brackets, the title of the article in single
quotation marks, the title of the journal

351.text:
in italics; bold or underlined, the volume,
issue and page numbers, the name of the collection

361.text:
in italics; bold or underlined, the phrase
"Online" in square brackets, the words "available

372.text:
at" followed by the url of the online journal
article, the word "accessed" followed by the

379.text: date you accessed the information in brackets.

386.text:
If you used information from a web page in
your work, then you need to include:

392.text:
The author or publishing organisation, the
year that the site was published or last updated

401.text:
in round brackets, the title of the internet
site in italics; bold or underlined, the words

410.text:
"available at" followed by the url of the
web page, the word "accessed" followed by

417.text: the date you accessed the information in brackets.
